title: Pro Bankruptcy Briefing: Evergrande Avoids Default; Judge Questions J&J Talc Venue; Mexican Steelmaker Mulls Chapter 11
text:
Evergrande makes overdue dollar bond payment. China Evergrande Group made an overdue interest payment to international bondholders, the state-owned Securities Times reported Friday, an unexpected move that allows the struggling property giant to stave off a looming default. But the pain is nonetheless spreading in Chinese junk bonds as the housing market slumps, dragging down real-estate developers that dominate China's international high-yield market.

Many international bondholders had expected Evergrande to fail to make its dollar bond payments before the end of a 30-day grace period. Chinese high-yield dollar bonds have already endured the worst selloff in a decade after Evergrande and several others skipped payments.

"We now need to track every single coupon and upcoming maturity."

— Jim Veneau, head of fixed income for Asia at AXA Investment Managers

Judge questions venue of J&J talc bankruptcy. A bankruptcy judge said he is unsure if his North Carolina courtroom is the right venue for a Johnson & Johnson subsidiary to try to settle tens of thousands of talc-related injury claims and suggested the case could be moved closer to the consumer goods giant's New Jersey headquarters.

Mexican steelmaker explores U.S. bankruptcy. Mexican steelmaker Altos Hornos de Mexico SAB de CV said it is exploring placing a subsidiary in bankruptcy after the WSJ Pro Bankruptcy reported the company was looking use chapter 11 to challege a $216 million settlement agreement its chairman signed with Pemex.

Bankruptcy

Puerto Rico Senate appears to snub restructuring plan. The Puerto Rico Senate indicated it wouldn't meet a Friday deadline to endorse a financial restructuring that would end the island government's bankruptcy. Senate President Juan Dalmau said there weren't enough votes to get behind legislation allowing Puerto Rico to effectuate a $35 billion public-debt restructuring.

The oversight board steering Puerto Rico through bankruptcy has said that without lawmakers' approval by 2 p.m. Friday, it would seek to cancel upcoming court hearings on the debt-adjustment plan. The bill's failure would mean more risks and costs as the bankruptcy case drags on, according to the board, which placed Puerto Rico under court protection in 2017.

The board also said Puerto Rico would be vulnerable to requests by creditors to collect their debts or dismiss the bankruptcy. Lawmakers have said the debt plan doesn't have enough money for public workers' benefits or municipal aid. — Andrew Scurria

Investors

Blackstone's profit nearly doubles. Blackstone Inc.'s net income nearly doubled in the third quarter, driven by strong investment performance for its largest strategies and continued expansion into fast-growing new business lines. Blackstone has also expanded into a number of fast-growing businesses including infrastructure, direct lending, insurance and products designed for individual investors that bolster its so-called perpetual capital, which doesn't have to be returned to shareholders within a given time frame.

In Other News

Daniel McNamara, a portfolio manager who made a fortune shorting shopping malls in 2020 during the pandemic, is forming his own hedge fund that aims to bet on distressed real estate. (Bloomberg)

Bankrupt gold miner Kumtor Gold Co. won court approval to borrow up to $10 million after defeating the Kyrgyz Republic's objection to the loan request. (Bloomberg)

Rep. Katie Porter criticized Johnson & Johnson on Twitter for moving to separate the Johnson & Johnson Baby Powder portions from the company as it faces cancer lawsuits from tens of thousands of women. (Insider)
